title: Locking ball and socket arm - Print and Assembly Optimized

description.text: All credit goes to alexrich82 for the original design, I've only done small tweaks to make it easier to print without supports and easier to assemble using either metric 10 and 20 wrenches or included printable versions. I'll design more end pieces to hold various useful things like magnifying glasses etc on an ongoing basis as I make them. I'll also add some other bits and bobs, compatible with "PCB Workstation with Articulated Arms" http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:801279 I love that design but the arms are very floppy, these arms are a nice upgrade to make them stay where you put them instead of sagging over time. I'll adapt the end pieces of thing to use the locking rings soon.

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

i3 Custom

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm, 0.3 for ring

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I recommend printing the "ball and socket" and ends with a 1-2mm brim, tensioner ring can be printed pretty much at max layer height for your printer, don't print the ball and socker or ends at finer layer height than 0.2mm, gets too smooth and doesn't hold in place well when locked.

In Slic3r the "Detect thin walls" setting has to be off or the teeth for the tensioning system are removed.

If your printer squishes the first layer to improve adhesion you might need to sand the bottom a bit, X/Y accuracy is important for the fit of this print, extrusion amount needs to be dialed in.

Assemble the ball and socket pieces with a ring between each but without putting them where they tension the cup, makes it very difficult to insert the next ball (as shown in one of the pictures), can't put them on afterwards, it's like heatshrink when soldering, put it on but don't fix it in place.

title: Da Vinci Cleaning Brush and Tool Storage - adapted to fit tools from da vinci 1.0a!

description.text: I was searching through for a tool holder that would fit inside my da vinci 1.0a and found the 'Da Vinci Cleaning Brush and Tool Storage', i printed it... when i tested it to fit the tools, it worked perfectly, but when i went to hook on the scraper, it wouldn't hook on... this is as the original holder was meant for the original da vinci.. This came with a thin plastic scraper whereas the 1.0a came with a thick metal one and the thickness of the 1.0a scraper was too thick to fit on the hooks, so i went in to tinkercad and lengthened the hooks to fit the 1.0a scraper, i did make sure that the hooks were not too long to hit the bed when connected to the ridges in the side of the machine...

Printer:

I used the Da vinci 1.0a

author: kaiboswell_

description.text:
MORE PRINT VOLUME:

  • Increased the lateral separation of 234 mm to 250 mm.

  • It has moved 10 mm heated platform down.

  • The resulting print volume depends on the platform and the extruder that we place but you can easily get a size bigger than 190 x 190 x 100 mm.
    • MORE ROBUST:

  • The thickness of the acrylic has risen to 6 mm.

  • The introduction of a crosspiece to give more rigidity.

  • In the attachment points of the rods can be placed brimmed washers (DIN9021).
    • DESING MADE CONSIDERING THE WIRING:

  • The electronics is on the left side of the printer, it is placed horizontally to get the cable up coming from above.

  • Parts acrylic have holes or slots provided for wiring.
    • ACKNOWLEDGEMENTS: Like last time, the magnificent infographics have been made with Cinema 4D + VRay by PIKELO. SPANISH VERSION AT: http://reprap.org/wiki/Prusa_Aire#PRUSA_AIR_2.2C_Redise.C3.B1o

To close the entire set will use a squads that I bought at the hardware store, I don't know as universal they are, so I put the plane and in any case can be made in ABS. The list of materials can be take from Prusa Air 1, you only need to add screws for squads and replace M8 washers of the rods by brimmed washers. To assure proper fit of the plexi pieces, but the thickness is 6 mm, slots is 5.8 mm. Therefore it is quite possible that you have to file them slightly. I HOPE YOU LIKE IT!!

author: IOaten

description.text:
I modeled this COD Ray Gun to be lit. I made the internal hollow to allow the passage of wires.
I used an over-head transparency painted clear blue for the visible part of the plasma chamber. The side gauge translucent parts were cut from a 1gal milk jug. The sound effects and some lights were from a $3 fake light saber I found at Target. I used two separate circuits for the lighting and sound. The switch on the side turns on the main lighting (blue, red, green and yellow). the trigger is a momentary switch which is linked to 2 AA batteries housed in the side gauge parts. This area also has the speaker and the sound board from the fake light saber. I also had to file down the hinge so that it would properly open and close.

I just updated the grip for the ray gun. I added the atomic symbol to the top. (I was mad I forgot it when I made mine.) I also made the battery compartment in the handle extrude all the way through. (I had to Dremel this out to fit a 9v battery when I made mine.)

On a side not I didn't bother making the sight as this would probably just snap if it were 3d printed. I was thinking one could just use the wand from a bottle of children's bubbles.

description.text:
I designed this to replace a lamp shade that cracked (probably IKEA). The critical part was the the bottom as it had to fit 2 notches in the lamp that hold it in place. Measured with a caliper and designed it to match the original part. Halted the first print early to make sure that the part fit correctly and notches matched.
Printed in PLA and have had it installed for almost 2 years. I'm using LED bulbs so no issues with heat melting the plastic.

author: Kaziya

description.text:
This is a self contained rail system to strap a large lipo and mount a Tarot T-2d gimbal to. It can then be balanced and centered on the bottom of any DJI Flamewheel multi rotor with four 8" zip ties. It's assembled on two 10" sections of 4 or 5mm carbon fiber rods. After the rods are in place a few 8" zips can squeeze the two rods together. I suggest supplementing this with something on the ends so nothing slides off.  
Edit: I just redid my rig with 12" x 5mm (I know, right?) and the longer space allows more room to balance if you'd like to move the camera far enough forward to lose the legs from the frame. This configuration will require an extra mini block (what holds the gimbal mount) I the center.

This is a model I designed a while back, It does not require any fasteners for the main frame assembly. You might need some screws for the controller board, motors and some good old zip ties for wiring, but you can put the frame together under 3 min.

Noted that for the upper and lower plates you might want to print with slightly denser settings for the infill.

It generally fits all small size control boards, at lease that's the idea...
I have 2206 motors on it with 3mm size mounting holes, I assume it fits most 22XX motors.
I use a wifi transceiver module so the video stream through wifi, which means I didn't have enough space for a FPV transmitter, bu I am sure you can zip tie it on the side or top.
I do recommend taking off the casing of the receiver if you are using regular receivers so that it fits inside of the frame and you can zip tie a FPV transmitter on top.

I previously put this model on Shapeways but they over priced everything so there is no point keeping it there.

remixed_from.author: fluxline
remixed_from.title: Ultimaker mount for Heavy Duty Spool

title: Hub for Heavy Duty Filament Spool - parameterised

description.text:
I'm using the excellent "Heavy duty printable filalment spool" http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:10219
and was using the elegantly designed "Ultimaker mount for Heavy Duty Spool" http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:33461
but wanted something more rugged.
There seems to be a general reluctance to drill holes in the frame of Ultimakers, but I have no such inhibitions which freed me to design this simple hub
There is not much room on the inside of the Ultimaker to accommodate nuts, but there is enough. One of the photos shows the nuts on the inside, and another shows the corresonding mounting dimensions for the upper mounting bolt
Although this unit was designed for my Ultimaker it may well suit several other 3D printers.
I've uploaded two stl files for the cap. I'm using 'MG cap plus 0_50.stl' but if this is a bit tight on the threads try 'MG cap plus 1_00.stl' (or scale up slightly in your slicer software).
I've also uploaded the OpenSCAD file which is pretty much fully parameterised for those who'd like to make other changes.

I printed this thing in DiamondAge natural PLA.
I used 0.1 layer thickness, 2.0mm side walls and 1.2mm top and bottom walls and 20% fill. No special reasons for these settings - just for information.
The cap stl isn't the right orientation for printing. Rotate it so the open end is pointing upwards.
Edit: Forgot to mention, mounted with 2-off 3mm x 20mm long screws and nyloc nuts. Washers under screw heads and under nuts.

remixed_from.title: Aerial Vista Security Camera w/Motion for Raspberry Pi

title: Security Camera using Raspberry pi 2 B and RasbPi camera

description.text:
UAVPilot did a brilliant job of designing his security camera and his instructions are very comprehensive BUT......
UAVPilot1 used a Raspberry Pi model 1 in his design, this is an update to use a Pi 2 B. The Pi 2 has the micro USB power socket on the side so the camera case has developed a nasty carbuncle on it's side to accommodate it!! This design also uses the official Pi camera module.
I found that in my windy location the camera moved about on the wall mount leading to false motion detection so I have also redesigned the mount.
So there are just 3 bits you will need from UAVPilot1's design that you will need, see his posting for printing instructions etc.

description.text:
Z-Level adjuster for the original RigidBot 3D printer. This allows you to fine-tune the Z-level using an M6 bolt by hand. Adapted for use in combination with Peter Stonehams stainless linear bearing mounts and fastened with M4 hex socket bolts with the plastic gantry holders as seen in photos. It is possible that it would work with the original plastic bearing mounts, but I have not tried (please let me know if you do).

I have seen several variants of this concept using smaller screws, but I've found the ones I've tried to be hard to stay consistent; The small screw would vibrate out of position or the level switch would be pushed further down over time. It could also be hard to line up the switch and screw to match.

My design uses a flat bottom M6 screw that will hit the level switch turned at 90 degrees from it's original position. This is easy to do by sight, and the switch itself will not risk being pushed further down as it's already at it's lowest position - this can of course vary with which bolt you are using.

Update 2016-04-09
Added a knob that fits on a hex bolt head. Aside from making it easier to turn, the illustration on it also makes it more intuitive which way to turn.

Printer:

RigidBot

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.15

Infill:

50%

Notes:

The mount can be printed as is without supports, but knob should be printed with supports. I would go with at most 0.15mm layer height.

When printed, tap the main bolt hole with a real M6 tap. When done, you should be able to fit a bolt with some resistance - in this case resistance is good, it keeps the bolt from moving out of place due to vibrations from the printer. If you cannot turn the bolt by hand, use a wrench.

Unscrew the rear gantry rod holder screws, place the endstop adjuster in front of it and screw it in place with two M4 hex socket bolts. There is a slot on the rear that allows the bearing mount screw to pass through the endstop adjuster. Mount as in the photos.

I was inspired by this model (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:463842) and the comments section to make my own.

Here are the improvements I made:
Thicker to maintain rigidity
With the pass through on the top, template should travel the correct distance, where other versions have an offset equal to the backwall thickness.
Feet are smaller so units can be closer when using template
Fully reversible to adjust for different nose lengths
Cutout to allow protrusion of many ship models

Post script - Acrylic is designed to hold 1/8" thick pieces. The other version is for the stock cardboard pieces.

Makerbot X2 Settings:
I've only used ABS so far with 3 shells & a HIPS raft.

Please comment on final fit. While the dimensions are over-sized compared to the actual measurements from a template, the print tolerances required different numbers.

This component is an addon to the set of excelent bed height adjustment components produced by JohnSL (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:103519). It replaces one of the bed clips in the top right position and adds an x-axis spectra cord tensioner. This means you don't have to dismantle your bed every time the cord gets slack and the x-axis starts slipping. Note: you must print this with support material enabled, and remember to remove it when finished, particularly from the center of the tensioner screw hole, and from the guide slot on the top that guides the cord, if you don't do that the cord will slip out when under tension. Because there can be quite an amount of rotational force exerted on the component, trying to rotate it about the bed height screw mount, i have added a tab with a hole for a screw to lock the component to the lower bed plate. However this will require drilling a small hole in the wooden bed plate to take the screw. It is recommended.
Printed on Printrbot Simple in Black PLA, Support material generation was turned on as IS required.

I adapted the current Prusa Mendel endstop by shortening the arm and moving a hole, to allow a standard 80mm PC case fan to be mounted on one of the lower side threaded rods. 
The fan blows across the build plate opposite the nozzle, and allows for extra cooling rates, particularly useful when printing small layers, or for preserving detail in others.

1) Print at least 1 holder, 2 if you prefer (although my fan is held just fine with 1).
2) Position holder on threaded rod, line up with desired fan position. The fan should just fit between the Z axis threaded rod and smooth rod without fouling either. I suggest you do this with your Z axis homed to ensure that the top of the fan isn't fouled by the bottom of the X carriage ends.
3) Tighten the holder so that it will barely move. 
3) Attach fan to hole in arm using nut and bolt. Tighten holder bolt to hold fan in position.
4) Hook up fan power
5) I turn on my fan after the first couple of layers have printed. 
I haven't used this with a heated bed though, and because it also blows on the underside of the build plate, it may antagonize the effect of the HBP, so YMMV.

title: Bahz Mondo, Space Scum (18mm scale)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Another speed-sculpt. Going with this whole "stream-of-consciousness alien design" thing.

This character was designed for our sci-fantasy tabletop RPG, Wayfarer: Things Beyond Wonder and for our modular wargaming system, Wayfarer Tactics. If you want to print a 28mm scale version, just scale it up by 166.6%.

We've set up a Patreon page for anyone who's interested in helping to fund us so we can keep making free and open sourced games like Pocket-Tactics, Wayfarer Tactics. and others, not to mention the growing catalog of gaming miniatures that you can use for whatever you want! (Psst... we take requests and commissions...)

Enjoy!

This is a parametric Reprap printer based loosely on the Printrbot design. It is designed for NEMA14 motors, 6mm rods, and LM6UU bearings, though the hardware can be changed by modifying the parameters in the scad file. The Reprap Wallace is now on github: https://github.com/whosawhatsis/RepRap-Wallace There is a video of an axis test using Marlin on youtube: http://www.youtube.com/watch?v=0QrEmGlZT0w&context=C3f40eeaADOEgsToPDskJ7qwV6fvNjtb93Wcpz_SHy More documentation, pics, and video on the Reprap Wiki page: http://reprap.org/wiki/Wallace

The best way to figure out the assembly is to open the scad file to see how the pieces are arranged. Also check out the images on this page and the wiki page to figure out how to assemble some of the trickier parts.

comments.text: I am trying to edit the scad file for wallace and the problem is I have 1/4 threaded rod instead of M6, but still have M6 smooth rods (I have alot of 1/4 threaded that I need to use) and I thought I would edit the value to standard form by converting mm to inches. However M6 is equal to 12 and M8 is equal to 15, so I am confused as to what the value need to equal. Thank you for the help
comments.author: apelpapa

comments.text: Yeah, separating the threaded/smooth rod diameters was on my list for version 2, before I decided not to design another machine using structural threaded rod. 1/4" is 6.35mm, and because all of the smooth rods are clamped, using that value for all of your rods will probably work. Another option would be to print the files for 6mm rod and then drill the holes for threaded rod out with a 1/4" drill. The diameter should be close enough that you can run the drill backwards to ream the holes out nicely without making it dig into the plastic.

comments.text:
Hey there! I have a question... I ran the Wallace.scad to calculate the rod lengths (I'm trying to create a 10x10 print area), but how do I calculate the size of the Y-carriage? Would I be correct to assume the length of the platform is the length of the Y-rods? What about the width?
Thanks!!
comments.author: PhatJustice

comments.text: The recommended method is to uncomment the line that says !platform(); and do a cgal render. This will produce a 2D version of the platform design suitable for exporting as a DXF (for lasercutting, CNC routing, etc.) with all of the various holes in the right places. You could also take measurements off of this file to get all the correct dimensions for the platform, but if you just want dimensions for manual cutting, echo out the value of the variable "platform_screw_spacing" to get the spacing of the holes for mounting the Y rods. Your Y carriage needs to be big enough to drill these holes without breaking through the edge of the board. I recommend a 10mm margin from the hole centers, which is what the DXF version will give you.
comments.author: PhatJustice

comments.author: whosawhatsis

comments.text: It can't pop off if it is assembled correctly. Unlike printrbot, there are no press-fits in Wallace. All parts are clamped or captive. Did you print "idler single-bearing.stl" or "idler double-bearing.stl"? "idler double-bearing" is shown in that picture, and you NEED two 623 bearings to assemble it. If you want to try to run with only one bearing per idler (not recommended), you have to print "idler single-bearing.stl" instead. In that version, the printed idler pulley is captive between the bearing and the Y idler piece (you will need a couple of extra nuts and/or washers for clearance). The "idler double-bearing.stl" part was never designed to be used with only one bearing, and WILL NOT work that way, as you seem to have discovered the hard way.
comments.author: Xendi

comments.author: jsturm

comments.text: Drill a hole and insert a screw with washers on both sides of the board and tighten a nut down to that it's rigid. Wrap the belt around the screw with the teeth facing toward the screw so that the belt meshes with its own teeth. When you clamp the two parts of the belt together with a zip tie, the teeth of the belt will hold it in place.
comments.author: jsturm

comments.text: The more I look at this design the more impressed I am. In the original printrbot the y axis stepper simply hangs off the base by the two screws; in this variant they act more like a pivot, with the inner side of the base acting as the main support. The fact that they're also used to secure the bearing clamps means less room for tolerance creep. Very clever engineering IMO.

comments.text: Just a quick follow-up to this...what's the difference between using the double bearing idlers over single bearing? Just makes for a more sturdy design? Also I'm thinking about adding a parameter to the scad so I can use 624s in future, was there any specific reason you chose 623s?
comments.author: whosawhatsis

comments.text: The double bearing configuration is a lot more stable. The single bearing pulley doesn't align as well, so the self-centering feature may not work, and the belt will likely ride the wall the whole time.
comments.author: Myndale

comments.text: I noticed in scad file that the first line is rod size=6. Should I change that when using m8 rods?
comments.author: MrJohn

comments.text: That's what the parameter is there for. You'll also want to change the parameters for the bearings. The comments in the scad file give you the measurements for LM8UU bearings.
comments.author: MrJohn

comments.text: It looks like if there were any stability problems, one could turn this into a stiff Mendel90-ish thing by printing 2 extra bases and shimming and bolting them through the feet-holes against an MDF frame like in http://hydraraptor.blogspot.com/2011/12/mendel90.htmlhttp://hydraraptor.blogspot.co...
comments.author: DaveX

comments.text: How are the MXL pulleys working out?
comments.author: DaveX

comments.text: They work great!
comments.author: DaveX

comments.text: Cool. That pulley is useful enough by itself that it might deserve its own thing page.
comments.author: whosawhatsis

comments.text: That was my intention. I actually designed it as part of another project that's much less complete and brought it into this because it worked so well. I intended to release it as a separate thing after coming up with parameters to use it with different types of belts, but I haven't worked on it for some time.
comments.author: DaveX

comments.text: Thanks for the help I managed to figure it out with some help from the IRC.
comments.author: MrJohn

comments.text: Most people don't know how to use open scad.
comments.author: MrJohn

comments.text: For an end-user, you basically only need to know these steps:
comments.author: MrJohn

comments.text: Thanks for that walk through.
comments.author: teppic

comments.text: Can someone explain how the Y axis belt hooks into idler and attaches to the bed? Even a picture of the underside of a functioning one would be insanely helpful  ;)
comments.author: rbaile28

comments.text: http://www.thingiverse.com/image:101021http://www.thingiverse.com/ima...
comments.author: rbaile28

comments.text: Thanks so much. That makes a lot more sense. :-D
comments.author: whosawhatsis

comments.text: I'm using your x-ends and x-carriage on a printer variant I'm making, and they really look good. But my printer is so small that I really see the need for either a custom extruder or for turning the extruder 90 degrees. So looking forward to the custom extruder :) ... I've attached a picture of my bot from above.
comments.author: larsie

comments.text: wow, that is tiny. What's your usable length on that X axis, about 50mm?
comments.author: larsie

comments.text: :) about 75mm right now. My aim was about 120mm. The printer itself is 250mm wide (not considering the x-stapper which is outside the base-frame). I sort of wanted to see how small it could get. My Makerbot has 10 cm x 10 xm print area, and for most things I'm happy with that.  There are probably various optimizations that could be done to almost reach 12 x 180 cm on this one. I used NEMA 17 for the z-axis, so might have saved a bit of space going for nema 14.
comments.author: whosawhatsis

comments.text: I put my files up on http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:15611http://www.thingiverse.com/thi... Maybe I should have marked it as a derivative, but I do give you a lot of credit at least, which you deserve. The base is not based on your design, but the top parts are made using your scripts. Thanks.
comments.author: larsie

comments.text: will you make a nema 17 model ?
comments.author: karandex

comments.text: If you check the SCAD file, you will see there are alternate settings in it for nema17 motors. The design is parametric, which means there are a lot of options to build it with different hardware. Until the design stops changing so much or I find an easier way to produce all of the STL files every time the design is updated, I'm not going to produce multiple STL distributions for the different hardware options, but you can always produce your own STLs from the SCAD file.
comments.author: karandex

comments.text: You can autogenerate the STL files with make, per http://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/OpenSCAD_User_Manual/Using_OpenSCAD_in_a_command_line_environmenthttp://en.wikibooks.org/wiki/O...
comments.author: whosawhatsis

comments.text: so including nema 17 what changes you suggest to scad file.
comments.author: whosawhatsis

comments.text: The scad file has comments in it about which values to use for Nema17 and also 8mm rods if you prefer that.
comments.author: karandex

comments.text: This looks awesome and I'm considering building one similar. I'm curious why you went with 6mm rods. My current and only printer is a prusa. I'd like my next build to be an advance in print quality and possibly build volume.
comments.author: Miro87043

comments.text: For my current build, I've got about 170mm available for building, though the rod lengths can easily be varied for a different size. I haven't had a chance to really put the machine through its paces, so I'm not sure if there are any stability issues left to fix. The X and Y axes are definitely stable at with 6mm rods, though it's possible that I'll want to switch to 8mm for the Z axis.
comments.author: Miro87043

comments.text: Possible to do nema17 and 608 bearings?  I have an abundance of these around...
comments.author: jkomp316

comments.text: Nema 17 can be done, there are alternate settings for it in the scad file. 608 bearings are radial bearings. The axes in this need linear bearings, so they won't work. It would probably be possible to modify it to use 608 bearings instead of the 623 bearings in the idler pulleys, but it wouldn't be easy, and would require more types of non-printable parts.
comments.author: jkomp316

comments.text: I made these up for 608 idlers. http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:15290http://www.thingiverse.com/thi...
comments.author: whosawhatsis

comments.text: I thought the assembly was pretty straight-forward, but you're not the first to have trouble understanding it.
comments.author: jkomp316

comments.text: Thanks for info, I'm going to try Triffid's printed lm8uu's on the build.  I'll post pics in a few weeks hopefully.
comments.author: whosawhatsis

comments.text: I'm looking at swapping the threaded rod and the smooth rod, so that the smooth rod is on the outside. It hides the z-axis motors, which seems a bit nicer. Is that simple to change in your design for the x-end left and right?
comments.author: larsie

comments.text: That would be a trivial change for the X ends, but significantly more complicated for the base.
comments.author: larsie

comments.text: Here is what I'd like to do: http://www.thingiverse.com/image:95169http://www.thingiverse.com/ima...
comments.author: whosawhatsis

comments.text: I just need the x-ends that is... not the base etc.
comments.author: larsie

comments.text: I don't see how it will increase the build area. If anything, it should decrease it a bit because you have to worry about clearance between the leadscrew couplers and the platform. Here's the code for the X ends with the smooth and threaded rods reversed: http://pastebin.com/P0PCVj6dhttp://pastebin.com/P0PCVj6d
comments.author: larsie

comments.text: Hmmm... Maybe you are right... Didnt think about the coupler...
comments.author: whosawhatsis

comments.text: Is the y build area maybe more dependent on the y carriage width? Would it make sense turning the extruder 90 degrees? And making the carriage less wide? Would it be stable enough? Thanks for the alteration...
comments.author: larsie

comments.text: Sorry. I of course meant X-build area, X-axis and X-carriage.
comments.author: larsie

comments.text: Sorry for spamming you here :-) ... I wonder if the stepper could be placed on the side, like this: http://www.thingiverse.com/image:96329http://www.thingiverse.com/ima... Maybe not good for balance?
comments.author: larsie

comments.text: Not great for balance, but probably not enough so to be problematic. It would mean that the idler would also have to be reoriented, which means more hardware because my idea to use the idler with the same screw that clamps the bearings in place won't work. It would also take up more space on the build platform to print.
comments.author: larsie

comments.text: I've tried to design a more portable version, with the possibility of lifting the print bed. It's on http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:14662http://www.thingiverse.com/thi... ... it's not a derivative of your design, but for many of the components, if I end up printing it, I'd use your components I think. The lower parts are different, but the z-axis I would choose from you, I think.
comments.author: larsie

comments.text: The 20 oz*in NEMA14 I use (from Pololu) have more than enough torque. They meet the requirements for a full-sized Mendel, and my parts are much lighter.
comments.author: larsie

comments.text: I'm thinking about your design, which I like.
comments.author: whosawhatsis

comments.text: I've given that a lot of thought, and if I were starting now from scratch, I might very well design it that way. I don't want to do that right now because I'm already planning to scrap the Y axis for a completely different design, though that is closer to what I have in mind, and I may end up building that as an optional configuration.
comments.author: misan

comments.text: I think making it portable is a good thing. Looking forward to seeing your design as it proceeds. I like your z-axis also.
comments.author: whosawhatsis

comments.text: Wiki page on RepRap (original created by whosawhatsis):
comments.author: casainho

comments.text: I like the update, also, it puts the strong direction of the print the direction where it will be most needed.
comments.author: twotimes

comments.text: It's where it's needed most if the carriage and the extruder mount are one piece. With the two bolted together as I was planning before, it probably would have been stronger overall, but if you really need strength along the length of the carriage, you probably have bigger problems...
comments.author: twotimes

comments.text: Are you planning on using M8 threaded rod for the Z axis?
comments.author: whosawhatsis

comments.text: My code is currently only set up for one rod size (for smooth rod, structural threaded rod, and leadscrews), though the size of the leadscrew nuts are a separate variable, so changing that to the size of an M8 nut would probably work. I'm thinking of changing this so that you can use beefier rods for the Z axis than the other two, and I could probably allow some other variation too.
comments.author: twotimes

comments.text: Makes sense. Good thing I have some lm8uus here also.
comments.author: whosawhatsis

comments.text: How is the snapfit for the linear bearings? and why is the hex tunnel open on for the z rod?
comments.author: LXDickman

comments.text: The hex tunnel is open for simple assembly/disassembly, and also to avoid an unnecessary bridge that might be challenging for poorly-calibrated machines.
comments.author: LXDickman

comments.text: I just did a test print of one of the X ends and the bearing press-fits seemed to work until I tried to use a heat gun to make them a little tighter. The crappy plastic that I'm currently using snapped, and the press-fits for the rods started to delaminate when I tried to insert them. The hex channel for the nut works really well, but I'm going to have to re-think the whole part to get rid of these issue... either redesign it to print in a different orientation or add some vitamin fasteners to replace the press-fits, maybe both.
comments.author: whosawhatsis

comments.text: Good luck
comments.author: whosawhatsis

comments.text: Posted. In fact, all of the files are updated, with at least a few tweaks in every part.
comments.author: LXDickman

comments.text: If done right, a press fit can work well for linear bearings (I haven't tested these ones, but I've got an unrelated experimental part using it) but I'm trying to remove them in favor of something more robust. I'm about to upload an update replaces the X carriage with one that doesn't use press fits.
comments.author: LXDickman

comments.text: Thanks for sharing!
comments.author: casainho

comments.text: Nice!
comments.author: larsie

comments.text: Niiiice! I like the way you made the blocks and bearing mounts. I was thinking 14's would be better for this design anyway. Now if you just had a simpler extruder...
comments.author: bwevans

comments.text: A custom extruder is on the list, along with a completely new design for the Y axis (one I've been thinking about for a LONG time, but never got around to implementing). I wanted to get a working version as soon as possible, so I decided to just give it a mounting point for a standard mendel extruder.
comments.author: bwevans

comments.text: Im sitting here at the moment working on a new bowden style extruder possibly for an emaker-ish huxley. I wanted something very small and that would work with a gearhead stepper. Not done yet and am already thinking of adapting to the printrbot style machine. All in time. Anyway great job on the fast development.
comments.author: whosawhatsis

This is a hard to print (but quick) test to check your printer and slicer capabilities.
It's useful to check and compare the resulting printing quality after each firmware update and to compare filament quality as well.

You can find three models optimized for nozzle size of 0.35mm, 0.40mm and 0.5mm, choose the one that matches your printer.

Useful things to watch in the print:

  • the unsupported bridges on back
  • the minimum clearance and wall thickness on left (nozzle size x 1, x 2, x 3, etc)
  • the minimum hole size on bottom (nozzle size x 1, x 2, x3, etc)
  • the details of two hemispheres, one filled and one empty
  • the precision of walls on the parallelepiped, from top counterclockwise nozzle size to nozzle size x 4
  • the details of the filled cylinder
  • the precision of increasing thickness walls on the empty cylinder (from nozzle size x1 to nozzle size x 4)
  • the unsupported spring
  • check dimensions of various objects in x,y and z to check your printer size precision. Take in account that the base is 1mm thick, hemispheres, cyclinders diameters and parallelepiped X and Y dimensions are 10mm.

I know there could be other interesting tests to add to this model, I'm working on it. If you want something specific please write me a comment, I'll take it in account when modeling next version.

Show me how your printer can print this model! (for sure better than my printer!)

This object gave me inspiration: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1019228 so I have to thank CtrlV :) (but this is not a remix)

Printer:

New Matter MOD-t

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

25%

Notes:

You can change slicing parameters and check the result with this object but I suggest to not use supports, to check the unsupported bridges and spring.
I tried Cura as well as Slic3r, both give different result, this model is interesting even to compare them.

Don't post process!

This is a printer test so it's important you don't post process, even for small details. If there are some wires due to dripping don't remove them! You want to check how printer is working...

This is a 2" bar mount that utilizes one of the standard GoPro bar clamp screws and a hinge.   
The hinge point is 3mm and I used a short section of 3mm threaded rod; however, the CAD files are attached, so this aspect may be changed to fit your style.  
The photos don't show the acorn nut recess for the camera mount; however, this feature has been added to the current STL and Thing files.   
Enjoy.

A while back the battery cover to my NXT got lost in a tub of bricks and hasn't been seen since. The missing cover never really bugged me until recently. Instead of trying to buy the part, I decided to print one! 
As it stands now, this is just a battery cover. But if it is added to something else, it may make the large flat surface on the back of the NXT even more useful. If not, this part will live out it's life as a battery cover.
Note: This was designed for the NXT 1.0. It may or may not work for the NXT 2.0.

1) Print out
2) Trim off supports
3) Install
4) Build great robots!

I had trouble printing the original so I decided to modify it for easier printing.  
I fixed up the model using Blender to get rid of internal geometries and intersecting shapes. I flattened out the base and made the antennas thicker (to avoid easily breaking them off). I also hallowed out the center to reduce plastic.

It's everyone's favorite Seleucid-era* toy, just in time for Hannukah! You know the drill: print it out, get some friends together, and battle it out for the future of humankind on this planet**! http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dreidel (* according to some sources. Actual history may vary.) (** well, chocolate coins. Still, chocolate's yummy!)

The dreidel was created in openscad; the script and DXF sources are included.
Print and attach a handle.  The hole in the dreidel is sized for an M5 bolt.  You may have better results printing out a separate handle, using a dowel, or setting the infill higher than I did; the bolt makes it a little topheavy.  Other than that, it spins pretty well!

comments.text: Whats the trick for a post?  Have you found anything in particular to get it to spin well?
comments.author: Camblonie

comments.text: I scaled it down slightly to use 3mm ABS filament for the handle.  Had to enhance the embossing slightly to keep it visible.  My MakerBot had a poor time with the cone tip (got melty).  Foolishly I gave it away before taking a picture, but I'll see if I can get one.

title: Case for Brother P-Touch EZ Tape cartridge

description.text:
A simple case to let you store your spare Brother P-Touch 'EZ Tape' label maker cartridges. I have a few different types of labels and wanted a way to keep them safe on the shelf away from dust/dirt/damage when not in the machine.

Model updated to make it easier to slide in cartridges and better viewing for label. Photos are of the old model.

Both parts are done as a single .stl to prevent translation/flip errors that spoiled my first attempt at printing, print them however thin walled you want. I did 3 perimeters 2 bottom, one top, 40% infill.
The two halves are acetone/solvent welded together and are a pain due to thin edges. There is alignment notches to make things easier.

comments.text: It was taken down to avoid confusion between the revision and original. Are you midway through building the original? I only ask because you could still follow the 'new' video. There isn't really any reason you can't follow the 'new' video with the parts from the original build.
comments.author: badger44

comments.text: Thanks, you were right. I was able to complete the build and it works great!! The only problem I'm having is the L.E.D. light. I'm not sure how you wired it to come on only when charging? I wired it so that it comes on when it gets powered up and its on all the time?
comments.author: Schematix

comments.text: You must be using the original design with the charge indicator LED. This was deleted to make room for the torch on the new version. In the original version the charge led had a 1n4004 diode between the dc power connector and the battery, This meant the LED would only come on when charging as the diode would block the power coming back from the battery. The diode was also deleted from the design because it was possible that not all smart chargers would function correctly with the diode installed. So for maximum compatibility they were removed. The short version is I'd just leave the LED disconnected. Bit of a bummer I'm sure but personally I'd rather not have a charge LED than a charger that has the potential risk of not correctly charging. There are otherways of using a charge LED but they are more complex than would probably be worth while
comments.author: badger44

title: Garbage collector support for Sunhockey Prusa 2015 S508

description.text:
Here is an interresting part easy to print which support a servo who collect the purge garbage.

I never seen this mod before and I encourage you to do it mainly if you're not near the printer when it starts.

You'll need to know a little bit of G-Code, how to customize Marlin and a start script in your slicer.
There is no standard config cause each printer and servos are differents so you should adapt your code with your configuration. Perhaps you'll have to do some hacks into Marlin and add some code with "servo.detach" if your servo has some jitter (Frequently seen).

The kinematic is like that :

1) Home
2) Autolevel on 4 points
3) Going to place where to purge
4) Servo garbage collector out
5) Purge quick and slow
6) Servo garbage collector in
7) Nozzle Wipe
8) Print

Check the video to understand what I mean.

The part I purpose here is the yellow one on the bottom left, easy to place without any screw and it's designed for a servo mini size like the Hitec HS81.

Everything fits on a Prusa S508 Sunhockey 2015.

description.text:
Another speed-sculpt. Going with this whole "stream-of-consciousness alien design" thing.

This character was designed for our sci-fantasy tabletop RPG, Wayfarer: Things Beyond Wonder and for our modular wargaming system, Wayfarer Tactics. If you want to print a 28mm scale version, just scale it up by 166.6%.

We've set up a Patreon page for anyone who's interested in helping to fund us so we can keep making free and open sourced games like Pocket-Tactics, Wayfarer Tactics. and others, not to mention the growing catalog of gaming miniatures that you can use for whatever you want! (Psst... we take requests and commissions...)

Enjoy!

title: Drop-in T Nut for 80/20 brand 10-Series Extrusion

description.text:
I designed this after ordering the wrong size T nuts.

The model is threaded roughly for an M3 (fine) bolt, but that resolution is beyond my printer's capabilities. However, M3 bolts do screw into this securely, as is. I'm sure it could be tapped or bored out for other threadings, as well.

This is intended to fit in 80/20 brand, series 10 aluminum extrusions, such as those used in TrickLaser's Rostock MAX METAL frame.
